unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: One-Sample T-Interval Output
question_text:
An exercise physiologist is interested in the effect of exercise on heart rate.
She has subjects walk slowly for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates. Then she has the subjects run vigorously for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates again.
The differences are recorded (heart rate after running - heart rate before running), with results below:
One-Sample T: Differences
Test of $\mu$ = $0$ vs. > $0$
What is a valid interpretation of the confidence interval given from the computer output?
What is a valid interpretation of the confidence interval given from the computer output?
tables:
VariableNMeanStDevSE Mean96% CITP
Differences1259.8810.363.66(51.22, 68.53)16.350.000

choices.text: Since the entire interval does not contain $0$, there is evidence the heart rate increased after exercise.
The increase in heart rate is probably somewhere around $16$ beats per minute.
Since the entire interval is above $0$, there is evidence the heart rate increased after exercise.
Since the $p$-value is not captured in the interval, there is evidence the heart rate increased after exercise.
Since the $p$-value is not captured in the interval, there is no evidence heart rate increased after exercise.

solution:
Anytime the entire interval is above what is being tested ($0$, in this case), it evidences an increase.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; this gives close to a correct interpretation, but it is more specific to say there really is an increase if the entire interval is above $0$.

Choices 'B', 'D', and 'E' are incorrect; having the $p$-value or test statistic in the interval has no meaning whatsoever.
